title: Environment Secretary admits 'air miles club' membership after climate change boffins call for BAN
text:
Theresa Villiers admitted she uses air miles as she was grilled on her environmental credentials today, days the Government's climate change advisers called for the travel perk to be banned.

The Environment Secretary, 51, admitted she was in 'the BA air miles group' and said that taking work flights in her role was 'inevitable'.

Her admission came after the Committee on Climate Change (CCC) said that points for free flight should be outlawed because they encouraged people to take additional, carbon-spewing flights.

In a report the CCC said frequent flyers should also be hit by an 'escalating air miles levy' to put them off flying too much, but measures should not raise prices for people taking an annual holiday.

Appearing on Sky News former Northern Ireland Secretary Ms Villiers was grilled by Kay Burley about her own personal environmental choices.

The Chipping Barnet MP told the broadcaster she drove a normal petrol car but 'in due course' would switch to an electric one because the Government wants to 'phase out' fossil fuel vehicles.

She was then grilled about flights, saying: 'I take flights but that is inevitable in my job.'

Pressed on air miles she added: 'I think I am in the BA air miles group. But what I would say is this environment bill is about supporting people to make environmentally friendly choices.'

There are approximately 220 frequent flyer clubs with an estimated total membership of 200 million across the world

She continued: 'We recognise that individual choices can't fix this issue by themselves.

'We want to support carbon-friendly choices and ensure we have an effective programme across Government, across business, to tackle these key environmental problems.'

There are approximately 220 frequent flyer clubs with an estimated total membership of 200 million across the world, many of whom take additional flights to 'maintain their privileged traveller status'.

The new suggestions are aimed at reducing air travel for the 15 per cent of the UK population estimated to be responsible for 70 per cent of all flights.

Among other aviation suggestions, the CCC said all flights should advertise their emissions in a plain manner easily understood by customers, for example as a proportion of an average annual household's output.

The report: Behaviour Change, Public Engagement And Net Zero, was authored by Dr Richard Carmichael of Imperial College London.

It said that 'high impact shifts in consumer behaviours' were needed for the UK to reach its goal of net-zero emissions by 2050, rather than the 'small and easy changes' suggested to UK households in the past.

It added policy changes were required which were 'consistent with the scale of the climate challenge, build optimism and commitment, and give weight to new ambitious narratives that inspire wide public participation.'
description: The Environment Secretary, 51, admitted she was in 'the BA air miles group' after the Committee on Climate Change said that points for free flight should be outlawed.
